nodes.bodyText: This seems inefficient, especially considering this method may be called for every field in an object (effectively making the traversal O(n2)). To make this more efficient, I was thinking that maybe this information could be stored in the TypeLayout/TypeLayoutEntry classes? TypeLayout also seems like a more natural place to ask this question, rather than the TR_ResolvedJ9Method.

I found TR_ResolvedJ9Method::definingClassFromCPFieldRef() already retrieves J9ROMFieldShape from VM when it retrieves the defining class. There is no need to build TR_VMFieldsInfo for the containing class.
Why does this have to be done under the lock? Since the string is in the constant pool and we don't need to do resolution to look at it?
The lock is not necessary since the API just checks the string. It'll be removed.
I'm guessing the lock is needed here because we might need to decide to flatten the field for the first time and might need to update the VM in some way?
This helper accesses J9Class::flattenedClassCache. It reads the cache. To prevent other threads from writing the cache, I think a lock would be required here.

To prevent other threads from writing the cache,

My comments above is not correct, clarified with @tajila, entires in J9Class::flattenedClassCache are only written during classload. They are effectively read only when being exposed to the JIT. I'll remove the lock next.
can you please add doxygen for the new APIs please?
